results.title: Kings and scribes
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Ancient lives”.
John Romer goes in search of the lost tomb of Herihor, emulating Howard Carter and his discovery of Tut’s tomb. He looks at the role of the scribe and in particular one man who collected the ancient coffins of pharoahs whose tombs had been plundered, and reburied them in order to safeguard them. When the plundered tombs were discovered, the Egyptians of the day, sang the funerary songs of their ancient counterparts as the pharoahs and their sarcophagi were taken down the Nile to a final resting place in the Musuem. The program also highlights recent archaeological investigations in the Valley of the Kings.

results.title: Community life, women and the Temple of Karnak
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Ancient lives”.
John Romer focuses on the role of women in ancient Egypt and their rituals such as birthing practices as well as reading some Egyptian love poetry. Romer explains the mathematical perfection of the Great Temple of Karnak, and provides an insight into the workings of the village oracle, the supernatural and medical treatment.

results.title: Ancient gold mines and temples
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Ancient lives”.
John Romer details the life of Paneb, one of the most extraordinary men who lived in the village of Deir El medina; village of the Royal Tomb makers. He also examines the famed erotic papyrus of Turin, visits the ancient gold mines where criminals were sentenced to a life of hard labour in the most inhumane conditions and tours the great temple of Medinet Habu.

results.title: The Royal tombs
results.creator_credit: Peter Spry-Leverton and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Ancient lives”.
The villagers of Deir El Medina, just outside Thebes, was the home of the Royal Tomb builders and painters of ancient Egypt. John Romer, British archaeologist explains how the villagers’ lives fitted into the highly organised Egyptian society. He explores the tombs in the Valley of the Kings and explains how the beautiful wall paintings and carved reliefs were executed and their changed design over time. The program visits Tutankhamun’s tomb, the temple of Deir El Medina, the village tomb of Ipy and the tombs of Kha in Turin.

results.title: Organization
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Lew Kraft, a successful and dynamic businessman, who is building a large shopping centre, opens up the intriguing and complex world of high finance and organisational know-how. The film then traces American economics from 18th century examples of community and farm organisation, through the complexity of the industrial and transportation revolutions, to modern-day international investments and multinational corporations and the organisational knack of Americans. With William Shatner.

results.title: Government
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Describes through the eyes of a middle-management Social Security employee, the role America’s government - the largest single employer, spender, borrower, and consumer in the country - has played in determining America’s economic growth. It tells why, and where the government has been involved in communications, agriculture, forestry, mining, transportation, banking and commerce, workers’ rights, health and welfare, and protection of the environment. Presented by William Shatner.

results.title: Innovation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Enterprise”.
Features John Tench, an industrial scientist who views himself as an incarnation of the traditional American inventor. Features the history of innovation in US technology; electronics, manufacturing, transportation, communications, engineering and business. The role of the US Patent Office is explained.
